Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 05:37PM - edited Nov 10, 2008 05:39PM by Alwayssearching I had my bilateral mastectomies with tissue expanders on Oct. 16th.  In bed, I used 2 bed pillows.  I own a back rest pillow from Target and the little arms on it irritated my drain area so I did not use that at all.  The best recomendation I have read about getting in and out of bed was to buy silky/slippery pajamas.  I did not read that until after I was mostly recovered but it would have helped a lot!  Moving in bed is a challenge because you cannot use your arms like you are used to - so the silky pajamas would definitely help.  With regard to the recliner, I own one and love it.  But I did not sleep in it after my mastectomies.  I needed to lie down in bed for sleep and like I said above, the two bed pillows adjusted as I needed worked just great.  I did splurge on 2 new pillows prior to my surgery.  I found Calvin Klein pillows at Macy's for $9.99 and I LOVE them. Good louck with your upcoming surgery.  The waiting is the hardest part.  It will be very painful but only for a short period of time.  I am three weeks out and am really starting to feel good again!

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2008 07:48PM Alwayssearching wrote: Thanks abby40 and others who replied.  We must have had our surgeries about the same time.  Mine was Oct 16th.  I am now drain free and, like you, slowly cutting back on pain meds.  I encountered some constipation from the narcotics so my PS switched me to Tramidol.  That is much better.  When I got my full pathology report I found out that I did not have a clear deep margin and my mitotic rate was extremely high.  So the docs want me to do chemo - and I thought I was not going to need it - so I am trying to decide about that now (it is such a process!) Thanks again, Sharon

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 08:28PM Alwayssearching wrote: Hi LIz, I also had IDC (2cm) with negative nodes.  ER+/PR-/Her2-.  Grade 3 (my mitotic rate was 64/64).  I also am BRCA1+.  But when I chose a bilateral mastectomy I thought I was going to be done.  When chemo was recommended and my grade status and mitotic rate, along with the less than 1mm deep margin, chemo seemed like a no brainer.  I want to stop this cancer dead in its track.  No one in my family who has gotten the cancer has survived it.  But I am going to even if it means a year of HELL.  Losing my hair is secoondary to all of the side effects of chemo.  I wish you luck in weighing your options.  Remember most of the side effects of chemo are temporaray.  Good luck, Sharon
